data.text: (THREAD) Technological innovation opens up opportunities and risks, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta at the @Bundesbank's conference “Future of Payments in Europe“. Our strategy is to empower Europeans with efficient, inclusive and secure payments in the digital age 1/5 https://t.co/Ukmp4K6lzI

Coming up at 10:35 CET: Executive Board member Fabio Panetta will speak at the @Bundesbank virtual conference ”Future of Payments in Europe“ about the payments revolution and the reinvention of money.
Follow live https://t.co/gMQo1Vtugb https://t.co/5cgBCrGcmA

Panetta: With Next Generation EU, euro area countries have taken a big step towards closer fiscal integration. They have also created the legitimate expectation of a common fiscal response when dealing with a common shock in the future https://t.co/8lSDZFPjYk 4/4

Panetta: We have the firepower, we have instruments that we can recalibrate, and we’re going to do so. Fiscal policy is also an essential element to respond to the crisis and to support our stabilisation goals 3/4

Panetta: With the second wave, the starting point for the inflation outlook is now lower than a few months ago. Uncertainty might leave scars even after the economy recovers. We cannot hesitate to take decisive measures to avoid a disanchoring of inflation expectations 2/4

(THREAD) We cannot afford to be too optimistic, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta to @Expresso. There should not be any doubt about our commitment to bring inflation back to our aim or about the continuity of our policies even when the recovery gets underway 1/4 https://t.co/KMi5i9C52R

Can the ECB improve fit and proper supervision although the rules are not harmonised across Europe? Yes – it will implement more efficient processes, enhance assessments and provide additional guidance to banks. Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/2nup7b1Juw https://t.co/T784r0s9oU
Account of the monetary policy meeting of the Governing Council of the ECB of 28-29 October 2020 https://t.co/ZNVJcAnpcc

Watch today from 14:00 CET (in English and Dutch): Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel listens to the concerns of people in the Netherlands and discusses the economy and monetary policy at a @DNB_NL listening event #ingesprekmetdnb #ECBstrategyreview https://t.co/7U1VkKEMrx https://t.co/kzbD5fWAdt

Lane: Ensuring favourable financing conditions to support the economic recovery and to counteract the negative impact of the pandemic on the projected inflation path is essential. We will recalibrate our instruments, as appropriate, to respond to the unfolding situation 5/5

Lane: Analysis by ECB staff suggests that without our monetary policy measures euro area output would be 1.3 percentage points lower and the annual inflation rate would be 0.8 percentage points lower by 2022 in cumulative terms 4/5 https://t.co/dYBRXMy8jm

Lane: The impact of the pandemic varies across countries while the services sector is clearly bearing the brunt of the pandemic. Fiscal policy is in the best position to differentiate and channel economic support to where it is needed most 3/5

Lane: While the recent news on vaccines is very welcome and reduces the likelihood of the most severe scenarios, the current surge in infections and the re-imposition of containment measures serve as warning signals that the recovery will still be long and fraught with risks 2/5

(THREAD) Chief Economist Philip R. Lane reflects on the role of monetary policy in a pandemic. 

Read the speech https://t.co/LUI6IlfBKt 1/5

Watch live from 13:00 CET: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane speaks about the monetary policy response to the pandemic at a special @TCDEconomics event.

Register here https://t.co/qsmn6AclAt https://t.co/yS8XZ4SLD1
How did euro area bank lending and money supply evolve in October? How do they compare with September figures? Find out more in the press release https://t.co/GtLNxK3JCE https://t.co/QKmNBYOIP4

We are lighting up our building for the #OrangeTheWorld  initiative, which marks the @UN International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women. This frequently hidden form of violence is one of the most widespread and persistent human rights violations. https://t.co/lDUdC4Wttg
Weitere Informationen zu den Maßnahmen der EZB während der Coronavirus-Pandemie findet Ihr auf unserer Webseite: https://t.co/WRu66o22OE
Vielen Dank an @Finanzfluss für dieses interessante Gespräch mit @Isabel_Schnabel über die Maßnahmen der EZB während der Corona-Krise. https://t.co/KcVTWymSZX https://t.co/BU6SEM86ti
Find out more about the ECB’s response to the coronavirus pandemic here: https://t.co/HJzEtFpSSL

How have the ECB’s monetary policy measures and the European recovery package mitigated the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic? Watch the second interview of Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel with @Finanzfluss: https://t.co/C8iR7vJWeX https://t.co/tExQYBMUCw
Working paper: Nowcasting business cycle turning points with stock networks and machine learning https://t.co/OGsqVsXBvo

Banks need to prepare for the end of the Brexit transition period to ensure that the EU financial system remains strong. Supervisory expectations are clear, but some banks are yet to complete their to-do lists. Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/2nup7b1Juw https://t.co/5KaezMLCcp

What do cycling and financial stability have in common? How has the pandemic affected the financial system and the economy? What risks lie ahead? Tune into the #TheECBPodcast with our economists @JohnPCFell, Tamarah Shakir and host @MichaelSteen https://t.co/43ndLavxD8 https://t.co/LZm85Cv1u2 https://t.co/XIszKz7GSx

Executive Board member Yves Mersch discusses the impact of the coronavirus on the eurozone economy and Europe’s banks in an interview with the @FT. He also looks back on his experiences as a member of the ECB’s Governing Council since joining in 1998 https://t.co/NI2XcIVKbF https://t.co/WlnOz3vw4w

How is financial stability faring in the wake of the #coronavirus shock? What are the key vulnerabilities facing the eurozone financial system and which challenges lie ahead?
 
Watch our video and read the Financial Stability Review to find out https://t.co/MPOGqIB2PO https://t.co/ZMZbFfrn9n
Watch live: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane joins an @IMFNews panel discussion on the challenges currently facing monetary policymakers. https://t.co/Y5xCsaW0Tz

Small and medium-sized banks play a key role in the European economy, but the fallout from the current crisis could affect their asset quality and solvency as struggling companies have spillover effects on banks. Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/2nup7aK85W https://t.co/ONhjTBsc8k

Watch live today from 14:15 CET: Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel talks at @SuomenPankki about how the coronavirus crisis has reinforced prevailing challenges facing central banks #MonetaryPolicyChallenges https://t.co/8jiagf63mc https://t.co/T1uhlZCb4w

(THREAD) Euro area SMEs report strong declines in turnover and profits across countries and sectors, reflecting the sharp fall in economic activity arising from the coronavirus pandemic. Yet, their concerns about rising labour costs have diminished 1/2 https://t.co/FpY0NRuy9q

How have green bonds fared during the pandemic shock and can they help green the economy? Could phasing out coronavirus-related policy measures affect financial stability?

Find out in a preview from our Financial Stability Review, which is out tomorrow https://t.co/vSCZv65xHM https://t.co/g9kXX2TJe5

Money markets have undergone structural shifts since the global financial crisis, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. While these changes have supported money market functioning during the pandemic, our policy response was also decisive https://t.co/EaV0toyxe0

The working group on euro risk-free rates and the ECB welcome @ISDA’s launch of the IBOR Fallbacks Supplement and Protocol. They will provide robust fallbacks for derivative contracts under ISDA documentation in case IBOR benchmarks will be terminated 
https://t.co/1lMM876H7p https://t.co/CVSXIwkOlQ

The working group on euro risk-free rates is seeking feedback on fallbacks for the Euribor rate via two public consultations. Interested parties are asked to provide their views before 15 January 2021 https://t.co/J2Ncr2dTJL https://t.co/k38KtuZQmz

The ECB’s Cultural Days 2020 were postponed until 2021 due to the pandemic. In the meantime, we hope you enjoy this special highlights video of previous events. We are committed to supporting shared European values also through cultural activities. https://t.co/gapdnty9k0 https://t.co/vmEf29gX1l
Working paper: Fire sales by euro area banks and funds - What is their asset price impact? https://t.co/aGGHKPMjzF

What challenges do firms face in the wake of the pandemic and why? What happens when credit ratings are downgraded and “angels fall”? 

Find out in a preview from our next Financial Stability Review, which is out on Wednesday https://t.co/iiEBzkFH58 https://t.co/RHiWl3Kqm2

Banks are having to adjust their governance arrangements in response to the coronavirus pandemic. What are good practices in this crisis and what actions would raise red flags in supervisory assessments? Read this and more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/2nup7b1Juw https://t.co/xbA27B3sUj

Lane: For the recalibration of our monetary policy instruments at our December meeting we have to decide which instruments are currently the most effective. So far, we have been indicating that the PEPP and the TLTROs have been very effective https://t.co/GTGjeyNE4p

(THREAD) Compared to spring lockdown, the economic impact is likely to be less strong this time, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane tells @LesEchos. The most severe scenarios are less probable now, but there will be some persistent damage and full recovery will take until fall 2022. https://t.co/9qMTKtxwFD
Read more about why stable prices are important for you: https://t.co/7EPbtvHEFu

Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel explained to @finanzfluss why the ECB aims to keep the euro area’s inflation rate at below, but close to, 2% over the medium term. See more: https://t.co/SeDwNuoBip https://t.co/w0LYqjak2f

Interview Yves Mersch with Börsen-Zeitung
https://t.co/lZX7awtRHG (EN)
https://t.co/FPIzQDuYzq (DE)

Decisions taken by the Governing Council of the ECB (in addition to decisions setting interest rates)
https://t.co/1QHMylvqQY

Što europski nadzor banaka znači za bugarske i hrvatske banke? O tome i o svojim prioritetima govore Martina Drvar iz Hrvatske narodne banke i Radoslav Milenkov iz središnje banke Българска народна банка (Bugarska narodna banka) u Biltenu nadzora banaka https://t.co/XjPh7hosrI https://t.co/ca8vrHX1SV

Какво очакват българските и хърватските банки от европейския банков надзор? Мартина Дрвар от централната банка на Хърватия и Радослав Миленков от БНБ обсъждат какво предстои и кои са приоритетите им в Надзорен бюлетин https://t.co/adhmwKUF7Z https://t.co/S5BozwPzPm

What can Bulgarian and Croatian banks expect from European banking supervision? Martina Drvar from the Croatian central bank and Radoslav Milenkov from the Bulgarian National Bank discuss what’s in store and their priorities in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/ZrvP8nHiE9 https://t.co/4ys0l329hA

Lagarde: To achieve this, decisive policy actions are needed. They lie beyond the remit of monetary policy, but will certainly affect our environment. I am confident that European policymakers will find the right way forwards. Read more https://t.co/iMhiNNHgfK 4/4

Lagarde: If Europe is to be successful in sustaining growth, it will require progress along a number of dimensions, in particular in harnessing the opportunities offered by new technologies. This will require a clear focus on innovation and education 3/4

Lagarde: Faster digitalisation offers many benefits. It could lead to a less resource-intensive economy, give a jolt to productivity and democratise access to essential services. But technological transitions have not always been smooth and can be a source of anxiety 2/4

(THREAD) The pandemic has rightly focused minds on the here and now, President Christine @Lagarde says in a speech at the European Banking Congress. Yet it also provides the opportunity to reassess how we will organise our economy in the future https://t.co/iMhiNNHgfK 1/4

The market turmoil in spring exposed structural fault lines in the non-bank sector, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. Macroprudential regulation needs to reflect that credit intermediation increasingly takes place outside the banking sector https://t.co/EeWJaASlXT
Working paper: Investment funds, monetary policy, and the global financial cycle https://t.co/60Pnnq94Uj
Working paper: Central bank digital currency in an open economy https://t.co/pYRyBhOSou

Watch: Roxana Mihet (@EconBitsStrings), the winner of this year’s #ECBForum young economists’ competition, shared with us the main takeaways from her experience at the #ECBForum and her plans for the future. https://t.co/ChAVj2inRd
Euro area monthly balance of payments (Sept 2020) https://t.co/x4FsIUxGBl

Lagarde: Public investment and reforms, especially if geared towards medium and longer-term challenges such as environmental sustainability and digitalisation, can build a bridge towards a successful and inclusive recovery.

Lagarde: Our measures have been very successful in stabilising financial markets and underpinning economic activity. We will address the current phase of the crisis with the same approach and determination.
Lagarde: Preserving favourable financing conditions for as long as needed is key to support people’s spending, to keep credit flowing and to discourage mass lay-offs.

Lagarde: The euro area economy is expected to be severely affected by the fallout from the rapid increase in coronavirus infections and the reinstatement of containment measures, posing a clear downside risk to the near-term economic outlook.
Letter from the ECB President to Mr Ernest Urtasun, MEP, on AnaCredit https://t.co/gMMRuQmnwW
Introductory statement by President Christine @Lagarde at a hearing of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament https://t.co/S8zqKf2s5p

Live now: ECB President @Lagarde speaks before the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the @Europarl_EN and answers questions from its members. Follow here https://t.co/PuGLLUq4Mg 
@EP_Economics https://t.co/MZ8goSx5lY

Tune in at 09:00 CET to watch ECB President Christine @Lagarde speak before the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee of the @Europarl_EN and answer questions from its members. Follow the webcast here https://t.co/PuGLLUq4Mg 
@EP_Economics https://t.co/p0etnLl203

Neue Formen der Kommunikation @ecb: Thomas Kehl @finanzfluss war zu Gast in der @ecb und hat mit @Isabel_Schnabel über Preisstabilität, negative Zinsen und die geldpolitischen Instrumente der EZB gesprochen. https://t.co/x8xiZrrprd https://t.co/tBnsTixzKU

Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel spoke with German YouTuber Thomas Kehl from @finanzfluss about the importance of price stability, why interest rates are negative and how the ECB has responded to the pandemic. Watch the first part here (in German). https://t.co/qtxr1u3ewf https://t.co/4niT60OToI
Legal working paper: Composite administrative procedures in the European Union https://t.co/mzY8dX54Bc

What can Bulgarian and Croatian banks expect from European banking supervision? How does the coronavirus impact banks’ governance and affect small banks? Are banks ready for the end of the Brexit transition period? Read the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/2nup7b1Juw https://t.co/pC8fHHSkLi

Enria: Supervisors can help to improve the cross-border integration of banks, for example by linking group support agreements to recovery plans. This will allow banking groups to deploy resources more flexibly and efficiently when responding to shocks https://t.co/f8AqJVx4wl 3/3

Enria: But as long as deposit insurance remains national, banking groups may not be able to smooth major shocks. A European deposit insurance scheme would dissuade governments from ring-fencing their banking sectors, which traps capital and liquidity within national borders 2/3

(THREAD) In contrast to previous crises, banking market integration in the euro area remained stable and lending rates did not diverge after the first coronavirus wave, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. The unified supervisory response was also a sign of integration 1/3 https://t.co/w4PdYNINM3
Interview @Isabel_Schnabel with @CNBC https://t.co/mbIu59i3Yo https://t.co/GR8GDsYBXs

Banks must be proactive in credit risk management, says ECB Supervisory Board member Kerstin af Jochnick in a fireside chat at the @IIF Annual Colloquium. Conversation topics also include banks’ use of buffers and the supervisory impact of the crisis https://t.co/V87p37mqEO https://t.co/3XKR7uWRja

At 11:30 CET today watch ECB Supervisory Board member Edouard Fernandez-Bollo discuss financial sector topics such as bank mergers, non-performing loans, the digital transformation, and bank regulation at the #EncuentroFinanciero event (in Spanish) https://t.co/qrl5mjAtEk https://t.co/zOwFXjqIYt

Hoy a las 11:30 CET puedes seguir la intervención de Edouard Fernández-Bollo, miembro del Consejo de Supervisión del BCE, en el #EncuentroFinanciero, donde hablará, entre otros temas, sobre fusiones, morosidad, transformación digital o regulación bancaria https://t.co/qrl5mjAtEk https://t.co/CNgA0UHil3
Welcome to Twitter! Follow @ESRBofficial for news and insights on preventing and mitigating systemic risks in the EU financial system. https://t.co/AgoSYJcNhm
Euro area financial vehicle corporation statistics (Q3 2020) https://t.co/H5rKeLzKiW
Euro area investment fund statistics (Q3 2020) https://t.co/UR8bs6VTEA
Watch from 00:05 CET: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane will be interviewed on the Tudo é Economia programme on @rtppt https://t.co/CAaYA1To4j https://t.co/VTZNRT3GXN

In the latest #TheECBPodcast episode, our guest Ulrich Bindseil talks about the advantages of a digital euro and explains how it would complement the digital payments that we have today. Want to hear more? Tune in with @MichaelSteen https://t.co/yBeazuTXZ2 https://t.co/Vzbw7ilwpj
ECB announces independent review of payments system outage https://t.co/iOyIAzMzUP

De Guindos: European bank valuations have been depressed by very low profitability caused by excess capacity, limited revenue diversification and low cost efficiency. The need to tackle these structural issues is now more urgent than ever https://t.co/SglcRhupB9 2/2

(THREAD) The coronavirus crisis has amplified existing vulnerabilities in the euro area financial system, says ECB Vice-President Luis de Guindos at the 2020 @eurofinanceweek. Banks’ credit risk has increased and profitability prospects have worsened 1/2 https://t.co/yXztQHqMYW

The speed of economic recovery is highly uncertain and depends on how the pandemic and related containment efforts evolve. But it is clear that fiscal and monetary policy measures play a pivotal role in protecting the economy from a persistent shock and excessive damage [4/4]
Digitalisation is likely to have accelerated in many firms across different sectors in response to the pandemic. This positive development may enhance productivity growth in the medium term [3/4]

Estimates of potential output are uncertain and will change as the situation evolves and as the pandemic’s economic impact becomes clearer. Yet, it is already evident that potential output is likely down less than GDP – indicating a negative output gap [2/4]

(THREAD) The coronavirus pandemic has lowered potential output in the euro area. Labour, capital, and total factor productivity were all affected. Read more in the #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/ogg0JaqZml [1/4] https://t.co/9D6rirlp0S

The ECB will preserve favourable financing conditions for as long as necessary, Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel tells @CNBC at the #ECBForum. At the Governing Council meeting in December, we will reassess the optimal choice, duration and intensity of our measures. https://t.co/o2BZzqyoD7

Congratulations to Roxana Mihet (@EconBitsStrings), the winner of this year’s young economists’ competition, and to all the finalists at the #ECBForum! Check our website to find out more about their research. https://t.co/AWZ1FX2Cuf https://t.co/e8AmatqTRA

This year’s young economists’ competition award ceremony is about to start at the #ECBForum. Follow the webcast and be the first to find out the winner, who will be announced by President @Lagarde and win €10,000. https://t.co/P93rcohD3D https://t.co/oyyf95b0fq
LIVE: The #ECBForum on Central Banking policy panel with Andrew Bailey, Christine @Lagarde and Jerome Powell, moderated by @khalafroula  https://t.co/p61MhbsQN7
Thanks to all of you who have taken part in the poll. Watch the #ECBForum policy panel live here on Twitter from 17:45 CET, where these and other issues will be discussed. https://t.co/zQnjnDzplV
Speech Luis de Guindos: Banking Union and Capital Markets Union after COVID-19 https://t.co/4Tb1dBFfpI

Starting shortly: Day 2 of the #ECBForum on Central Banking examines macroeconomic stabilisation frameworks in a new economic environment.

Watch live on our website https://t.co/P93rcohD3D https://t.co/VgCVbznRYu
Economic Bulletin: Country-specific data used for 42 trading partners, covering 92% of euro area foreign demand
Economic Bulletin: External environment projection weights now also account for traded services

Economic Bulletin box : A revised weighting scheme for the international environment projections
https://t.co/wRdVSdjTl9 https://t.co/WVKjSqYYDN

Economic Bulletin Issue 7, 2020
https://t.co/vXMcS6Adp4 https://t.co/2xe7YKhcPK

Starting now: Session 1 of the #ECBForum on Central Banking examines the implications of fundamental global changes for central banks.

Watch live on our website https://t.co/P93rcohD3D https://t.co/YILf9R7BTw

Lagarde: The European policy mix has proven that when different authorities work together, countries can successfully absorb the pandemic shock. The second wave presents new challenges and risks, but the blueprint for managing it is the same https://t.co/783Wy8WRHs 6/6
